page.title: Cystic Fibrosis (CF)
page.content: Cystic Fibrosis (CF) Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an inherited disease that causes thickened mucus to form in the lungs, pancreas and other organs. In the lungs, this mucus blocks the airways, creating lung damage and making it hard to breathe. CF is a life-threatening condition, but thanks to advances in treatment and care, the average life expectancy has been steadily increasing and quality of life has improved. Learn About Cystic Fibrosis Cystic fibrosis is a genetic (inherited) condition that leads to frequent sinus and lung infections, as well as digestive problems. Learn what causes this disease and who is at risk. Read More Cystic Fibrosis Symptoms and Diagnosis All newborns in the U.S. are screened for cystic fibrosis, so diagnosis often occurs before symptoms develop. Read More Treating and Managing Cystic Fibrosis In the last few decades, significant strides in treatment have been made so that children born today with CF have a completely different outlook than those born several decades ago. Read More Questions to Ask Your Doctor about Cystic Fibrosis Being diagnosed with CF is life-changing not only for the patient but for the family. That is why making notes before your visit, as well as taking along a trusted family member or friend, may be helpful when talking to your doctor.
